results.title: Bottles into dolls
results.creator_credit: Children's Library and Craft Movement, Arthur Cantrill and Corinne Cantrill
results.brief_description: Children learn to enjoy the art of making dolls from bottles, with plasticine. Imaginative use is made of a variety of materials at Brisbane’s Creative Leisure Centre. Costumes may be sewn, pinned or glued on to the figure and arms joined on with strips of plasticine. Finished figures are lined up and music-makers accompany the procession of completed dolls.

results.title: Botticelli: visions of beauty and violence
results.brief_description: Sandro Botticelli was one of the most popular and sought after artists of the Renaissance, renowned for his religious and mythological subjects and the beauty and sensuality of his painting. Working almost exclusively out of Florence, except for a stint in Rome to paint frescos for the Sistine Chapel, the bulk of his output was commissioned work for wealthy patrons such as the powerful Medici family. His friend and benefactor, Lorenzo di Pierfrancesco de’ Medici, commissioned Botticelli to provide illustrations for a copy of what has been viewed as the greatest ever work of Italian literature - Dante Alighieri’s Divine Comedy. Given complete artistic control over the project, Botticelli worked on the drawings between 1480 and 1495, and although they remain unfinished, they are viewed as some of the most enduring examples of his stylistic virtuosity. Working closely with Dante’s text, he painstakingly created illustrations for each section of the poem on fine goatskin parchment, expertly creating a visual interpretation of the poet’s epic passage through Hell, Purgatory and Paradise. A selection of art experts discuss the spiritual and political content, historical background and artistic execution of this work, and speculate on what drove this “explorer of beauty” to produce such a unique and animated accompaniment to Dante’s written account of the journey of the soul.

results.title: Botanic man. - Volume 3: Episodes 8-10.
results.creator_credit: Thames Television International, Randal Beattie, Graeme Duckham and Robert Fleming
results.brief_description: A compilation of David Bellamy’s “Life on the limit”, Extinction is forever”, and “Crackpot jackpot”. Contents include the ecological consequences of agriculture, the extinction of species, and the human role in evolution.

results.title: Botanic man. - Volume 2: Episodes 5-7.
results.creator_credit: Thames Television International, Randal Beattie, Graeme Duckham and Robert Fleming
results.brief_description: A compilation of David Bellamy’s “Land of opportunity”, “Latitude zero”, and “White death: new life”. Contents include the botanical uniqueness of New Zealand, the role of animals in plant reproduction, the ecological contrasts of Ecuador’s Andes, and the glacial origins of Canada’s wheatlands.

results.title: Botanic man. - Volume 1: Episodes 1-4.
results.creator_credit: Thames Television International, Randal Beattie, Graeme Duckham and Robert Fleming
results.brief_description: A compilation of David Bellamy’s “Greenprint for life”, “The Crucible of life”, “Living Water”, and “Potential energy”. Contents include Amazon rain forest ecology, the emergence of the earliest life forms, marine ecology and the Peruvian trench, the evolutionary transition from sea to land and its legacy of peat and coal deposits.

results.title: Botanic man
results.brief_description: An amazing 10-part series, tracing the evolution and adaptation of life on earth. The programs take a botanical point of view because it is the plants that form the basis of the energy web which enables life as we know it to exist in this world.

results.title: Boswelle's bon voyage
results.brief_description: Relates the adventures of a dog named Boswelle, who stows away on a ship going to Europe and North Africa. Narrated by Wayne Tippit.

results.title: Boston: the art of a city
results.creator_credit: Cinemagraphics, Yale Marc and Jim Herzig
results.brief_description: Surveys professional, amateur, and personal cultural life of Metropolitan Boston, including the Boston Symphony Orchestra, the Boston Ballet, the Opera Company, folk dancing, singing, painting, and other activities.

results.title: Boston Symphony Orchestra
results.brief_description: The Boston Symphony Orchestra in Japan in 1960, conducted by Charles Munch and Aaron Copland, includes performances of sections of major works with narration kept to a minimum. Includes complete movements or sections from the following: Easley Blackwood Jnr - “Symphony No. 1”; Hector Berlioz - “Symphony Fantastique”; Aaron Copland - “The Tender Land”; Claude Debussy - Symphonic Poem “La Mer”.
